subject: Re: [junit] Re: Expected exception pitfall and pattern
msgSnippet: ... Another work around is to have another test that verifies the behaviour up to the point where the exception is expected. This wouldn t be expecting the
messageBody:
On 29/11/05, Jon Skeet <jon.skeet@...> wrote:
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Kent Beck" <kentb@e...> wrote:
> > I can see the potential problem, but I've never experienced it so
> > I'm not inclined to add anything to the framework to deal with it.
>
> Makes perfect sense :)
>
> > The two workarounds I can see are to write the try/catch yourself or
> > (in the case below) to move the Account creation to a @Before
> > method.

Another work around is to have another test that verifies the
behaviour up to the point where the exception is expected. This
wouldn't be expecting the exception, and so would presumably fail if
the exception was thrown.

> Right. Of course, in various other situations you really need a
> try/catch anyway (for instance, verifying mock object interaction), so
> it's just an extension of that.

I personally don't like expecting exceptions in tests because I wish
to verify the state of the exception, but each to their own...
